title.value: Thanks to low interest rates, housing still affordable to many Americans despite increase in prices, Milken Institute study finds

value:
LOS ANGELES — Despite continuing increases in housing prices, millions of Americans can still afford to buy their own home thanks to historically low interest rates and rising household incomes, a new study from the Milken Institute shows.But if those rates rise, or if housing prices grow faster than incomes, the American dream of homeownership will disappear for many, the authors say. "If mortgage rates do not rise in the near future, and income growth remains strong, the demand that supports the current prices can be expected to remain stable for the near term," write the authors, Research Economist Susanne Trimbath and Research Analyst Juan Montoya. "Like a tripod, however, if one of the three dimensions — home prices, household income and mortgage interest rates — moves faster or opposite to the other two, it has the potential to upset the current balance of affordable housing in the U.S." Looked at from the point of view of home prices versus income, affordability is at near-record lows, the study says. But because mortgage rates are also at near-record lows, it has allowed Americans to continue buying, they say. Among the study′s findings: o Home affordability is near record lows based on the ratio of home prices to income. Today, that figure is 4.14, close to the maximum of 4.19 reached in 1988.
o But the ratio of mortgage payment to income for median-income households is low — 32.4 percent, compared to 40.5 percent in 1988. (See figure below.)
o The current supply of housing is 3.9 months, among the lowest ever.
o Far fewer minorities can afford homes than whites, mainly because of lower income levels. Housing Affordability and New House Sales Source: U.S. Census Bureau, Bloomberg, Milken Institute According to the study, simple supply and demand economics is at work in the real estate market. "Recent low interest rates have dramatically increased housing affordability for many Americans, creating a concomitant increase in demand," the authors state. "This demand, however, has not been met with a proportionate increase in supply, creating a very tight residential real estate market that has driven prices upward." But because interest rates are low, the delicate balance between prices, income and interest rates has been maintained — something that should continue for the near future. "Since interest rates are not expected to rise in the near future, and income is experiencing strong growth, the demand that supports the current prices can be expected to remain stable for the near term," they write. View Housing Affordability in Three Dimensions: Price, Income and Interest Rates (pdf).
